pullRequest.body:
This PR defines [Hilbert C⋆-modules](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hilbert_C*-module). A Hilbert C⋆-module is a complex module `E` together with a right `A`-module structure, where `A` is a C⋆-algebra, and with an "inner product" that takes values in `A`. This inner product satisfies the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, and induces a norm that makes `E` a normed vector space.

This is a stepping stone towards proving that matrices with entries in a C⋆-algebra are a C⋆-algebra, which is in turn needed to define completely positive maps.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> Mathlib.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

### PR summary [d90eb924f8](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/15244/commits/d90eb924f813e99e8b365233ecf9db58b6e95764)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|
| `Mathlib.Analysis.CstarAlgebra.Module`|1943|

</details>

---

<details><summary>

#### Declarations diff

</summary>

`+ CstarModule`
`+ continuous_inner`
`+ innerSL`
`+ innerSL_apply`
`+ inner_add_left`
`+ inner_mul_inner_swap_le`
`+ inner_neg_left`
`+ inner_neg_right`
`+ inner_op_smul_left`
`+ inner_self_eq_norm_sq`
`+ inner_smul_left_complex`
`+ inner_smul_left_real`
`+ inner_smul_right_real`
`+ inner_sub_left`
`+ inner_sub_right`
`+ inner_sum_left`
`+ inner_sum_right`
`+ inner_zero_left`
`+ inner_zero_right`
`+ innerₛₗ`
`+ innerₛₗ_apply`
`+ isSelfAdjoint_inner_self`
`+ norm`
`+ norm_eq_csSup`
`+ norm_inner_le`
`+ norm_nonneg`
`+ norm_pos`
`+ norm_sq_eq`
`+ norm_triangle`
`+ norm_zero`
`+ norm_zero_iff`
`+ normedSpaceCore`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

</details>

> Is there are reason the polarization identity is not included here? Is that because we can't have modules over non-unital `A`?

Yes: I haven't come across it, and it wasn't needed so far. How does it work for Hilbert C*-modules? I mean, I don't see how you could recover an `A`-valued inner product from the real-valued norms.

> > Is there are reason the polarization identity is not included here? Is that because we can't have modules over non-unital `A`?
> 
> Yes: I haven't come across it, and it wasn't needed so far. How does it work for Hilbert C*-modules? I mean, I don't see how you could recover an `A`-valued inner product from the real-valued norms.

You just use the inner product of an element with itself (but don't take the norm of the resulting element of `A`) in place of the norm squared.
It can come in a separate PR though. I don't think you need modules over non-unital rings.

:v: dupuisf can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10191618211/job/28193152845)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/10191618211/job/28193152742)
bors d+
I'm interested to hear your thoughts on some of these issues.

Sorry, I found a few more things.

Is there are reason the polarization identity is not included here? Is that because we can't have modules over non-unital `A`?
bors d+
I think it's safe to just call the file name `Module`.

I would like to call it just `CstarModule`, or potentially `HilbertModule`. Although the literature prefers the latter abbreviation, I have a slight preference for the former, because the latter tends to come with a completeness assumption. What do you think?
So long as the C*-norm condition appears, it's probably justifiable to abridge this to `CstarModule`...and this condition indeed appears on line 59.
I'd be happy to rename it to `CstarModule` (I was actually hesitating between `CstarModule` and `HilbertCstarModule` anyway).
Do you think we could get away with some sort of scoped notation `⟪x, y⟫⋆_A` or something that would elaborate like `⟪x, y⟫_𝕜` does?
Actually I think we can get away with `⟪x, y⟫_A`, this local notation is just to avoid having to write the `_A` all the time.

I do feel like it's important to stick with literature here and go with right `A`-modules, but that `SMul Aᵐᵒᵖ` does make me slightly nervous.

A more significant point though: while I'm impressed you managed to do this much with only `SMul` (I'm surprised Cauchy-Schwarz was possible!), you're about to run into a major headache as soon as you try to do anything else, at least while allowing for non-unital `A`. This is because we have no `NonUnitalModule A E` class which satisfies all the usual module axioms, except allows `A` to be non-unital by dropping `1 • x = x`.

Do you have a plan for this? If so, I'd be interested. My tentative plan thus far has been: since `ℂ` is already baked into this type class, we take a `Module (Unitization ℂ A) E` instance along with an `IsScalarTower A (Unitization ℂ A) E` instance. The downside is that we need to have domain-specific lemmas for the standard module lemmas. We can't even generalize these because there would be no way for Lean to infer `ℂ` (because in general it would be some `R` instead).

On a separate note: this structure doesn't allow for real C⋆-modules, which is a bit of a shame, but these are much less studied even than real C⋆-algebras themselves, so I think we'll just let it slide. We can generalize at a future date. One problem at a time I suppose!

I already got quite far with this: I have a complete proof that matrices with entries in a C*-algebra is a C*-algebra that I'll probably PR tonight, and I have not felt any pain related to this at all. Actually, in a previous version I tried to avoid the right `A`-modules and it was horrible: you do need right multiplication somewhere, and I think this is much less painful than the alternatives, like having the matrices act on the right on row vectors.

As for getting to applications where we really need to work with `NonUnitalModule` in a nontrivial way: is it urgent enough to resort to hacks instead of just biting the bullet and actually writing `NonUnitalModule`?
We really need an `abbrev class` for `NonUnitalCstarAlgebra`.
Oh yes!

I've realized that this also holds for C⋆-modules which only have a `SeminormedAddCommGroup`, but the proof is significantly more complicated. At some point, it would be nice to generalize, but I don't think that it's urgent.

Two issues here:

1. This doesn't belong here (I know Erin's thesis had it though)
2. We'll just want an `OrderedSMul ℝ A` instance instead. Then we'll get all this for free.

I'll write up the instance in another PR today.
I just deleted it from this PR, turns out I wasn't even using it.

:golf:
```suggestion
  refine Eq.symm <| IsGreatest.csSup_eq ⟨⟨‖v‖⁻¹ • v, ?_, ?_⟩, ?_⟩
  · simpa only [norm_smul, norm_inv, norm_norm] using inv_mul_le_one_of_le le_rfl (by positivity)
  · simp [norm_smul, HilbertCstarModule.inner_self_eq_norm_sq, pow_two, ← mul_assoc]
  · rintro - ⟨w, hw, rfl⟩
    calc _ ≤ ‖w‖ * ‖v‖ := norm_inner_le E
      _ ≤ 1 * ‖v‖ := by gcongr
      _ = ‖v‖ := by simp
```

for normal inner products this, combined with the following, is called [innerₛₗ](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Basic.html#inner%E2%82%9B%E2%82%97). The continuous version, which I think you should also add in this PR, is called [innerSL](https://leanprover-community.github.io/mathlib4_docs/Mathlib/Analysis/InnerProductSpace/Basic.html#innerSL). Can we make the names and API match a bit better?
Done.

```suggestion
/-- The C⋆-algebra-valued Cauchy-Schwarz inequality for Hilbert C⋆-modules. -/
```

Unless there's a reason not to:
```suggestion
@[simp]
lemma innerSL_apply {x y : E} : innerSL x y = ⟪x, y⟫_A := rfl
```

I think I'd rather not: I've used these lemmas backwards more often than forwards, so that I could use the properties of the bundled object. I don't think it's likely to show up out of the blue since we're pretty much always using the bare function.

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(CstarAlgebra): define Hilbert C⋆-modules
